Graphical abstract This review summarized and discussed the mechanisms of self-discharge supercapacitors, with a focus on suppressing strategies in terms of electrode, electrolyte, and separator. The remained challenges and the promising directions in suppressing the self-discharge of supercapacitors were also presented and summed up. Supercapacitors are one of the most promising energy storage devices in the fields of vehicle transportation, flexible electronic devices, aerospace, etc. However, the existed self-discharge that is the spontaneous voltage decay after supercapacitors are fully charged, brings about the wide gap between experimental studies and practical utilization of supercapacitors. Although eliminating the self-discharge completely is not reachable, suppressing the self-discharge rate to the lowest point is possible and feasible. So far, the significant endeavors have been devoted to achieve this goal. Herein, we summary and discuss the possible mechanisms for the self-discharge and the underlying influence factors. Moreover, the strategies to suppress the self-discharge are systemically summed up by three independent but unified aspects: modifying the electrode, modulating the electrolyte and tuning the separator. Finally, the major challenges to suppress the self-discharge of supercapacitors are concluded and the promising strategies are also pointed out and discussed. This review is presented with the view of serving as a guideline to suppress the self-discharge of supercapacitors and to across-the-board facilitate their widespread application. Keywords Supercapacitors Self-discharge Mechanism Suppressing strategy 1 Introduction In the last decades, with the rapid growth and development of global economy, total demand for the fossil fuel (coal, petroleum and natural gas) has grown greatly. According to the reported statistics, the needs for total equivalent oils in the world will increase up to 18.30 billion tons by 2035 [1]. Huge energy consuming and requirements are urgently calling for the development of the renewable energy, which correspondingly brings about many tough energy storage issues [2]. Therefore, developing energy storage devices with high efficiency is highly desired [3–5]. As one type of promising electrochemical energy storage devices, since supercapacitors were firstly reported in 1957, it gradually attracted increasing attention owing to the high energy efficiency (90%–95%), superior power density (up to 10 kW kg−1) and long cycle life (~105 cycles) [6–10]. Typically, relying on the energy storage mechanism, supercapacitors can be categorized into the electric double layer capacitors (EDLC) and pseudocapacitors [11]. For EDLC, it stores the energy via electrostatic adsorption of ions on the surface of electrode, while the pseudocapacitors stores energy mainly through the reversible redox reactions on the surface/near-surface of electrode materials (such as conducting polymers, metal oxides/hydroxides/ oxyhydroxides, metal sulfide/phosphide, MXene etc.) [12–23]. So far, a series of strategies have been proposed to intensify the electrochemical performance of supercapacitors and the results are fascinating. For example, the 2D carbonaceous nanosheets were used as electrode to enhance the ionic transport ability, with a capacitance up to 246 F g−1 at 100 A g−1 [24]. The layered double hydroxide coupled on the carbon cloth was used as the positive electrode of asymmetric supercapacitors with activated carbon negative electrode to improve both of the energy density (69.7 Wh kg−1) and the power density (0.8 kW kg−1) [16]. The montmorillonite/polyvinyl alcohol hydrogel electrolyte was chosen to widen the temperature changing from −50 to 90 °C of supercapacitors [25]. The 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (EMI-TFSI) and 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (EMI-BF4) ionic-liquid (IL) electrolytes were mixed to expand the operating voltage window of supercapacitors (~3.5 V) [26]. The acetonitrile was added into the water-in-salt (WIS) electrolyte to improve the conductivity [27]. However, although many impressive results have been reported, the severe self-discharge still serves as one of the significant bottleneck issues during the application process of supercapacitors [28]. Generally speaking, the self-discharge is a spontaneous voltage drop process under the open circuit condition of supercapacitors, due to a high and negative Gibbs free energy [29,30]. After the supercapacitors are fully charged, the charges in electric double layer (EDL) will be consumed at a fast rate derived from the spontaneous diffusion of electrolyte ions in EDL and parasitic Faradic reaction, and soon afterwards the open-circuit voltage will decline in a nonlinear way. The undesired self-discharge led to the significant decay of the capacitance and a poor cycle-life, finally, imposing the huge negative impacts on the scope of the application of supercapacitors. It was reported that about 5%–60% loss of voltage would happen within two weeks due to the fast self-discharge process causing the huge loss in energy [31]. To explore this field, great efforts have been devoted to clarify the basic mechanisms of self-discharge for efficient charge storage [31,32]. To respond the problems, three kinds of fundamental mechanisms for the self-discharge in supercapacitors were proposed by Conway: leakage current, Faradic reaction and charge redistribution [33]. With this information in mind, the fundamental and influence factors of self-discharge were also further decoupled and revealed by many researches in energy-storage field. In this regard, the oxygen functional groups of electrode, pore structure of electrode, impurities of electrolyte, operation temperature and charge current density during charging process, were finely investigated and confirmed to have great influences on the self-discharge rate [34–37]. The detailed analysis regarding the influence factors of self-discharge was discussed as follows. To begin with, the electrode materials with porous structure would produce the pore effects, leading to the undesired charge redistribution [35]. On the other hand, the oxygen groups on the surface of electrode materials will weaken the interaction between electrolyte ions and electrode surface and react with the electrolyte leading to the enhancement of the self-discharge [38]. Moreover, the impurities of electrolyte will bring about the shuttle effects to increase leakage current [37]. Furthermore, the operation temperature mainly affected the viscosity of the electrolyte especially for the organic electrolyte. Generally, the high operation temperature would reduce the viscosity of electrolyte resulting in the fast self-discharge rate [36]. Last but not least, the self-discharge rate was proportional to the charge current density, where the low charge current density allowed the ions near the surface of electrode to have much time to form more stable EDL, finally restricting the self-discharge process [36]. Of course, it is noted that the number of published papers related to the self-discharge rapidly increases in the past decade (Fig. 1 , data are from Web of Science). Finally, the summarized mechanisms of the self-discharge always help and guide the researchers to well carry out the related work. As a result, the novel and creative strategies have been presented to suppress the self-discharge. In this review, we introduced and discussed the mechanisms of the self-discharge including the leakage current, the Faradic reaction and the charge redistribution with a focusing on summarizing the latest strategies to suppress the self-discharge in terms of modifying the electrode, modulating the electrolyte and tuning the separator (Fig. 2 and Table 1 ). Meanwhile, the great challenges of suppressing the self-discharge were also pointed out. Moreover, the possibly promising direction and strategies to suppress the self-discharge were discussed and proposed in future. 2 Mechanisms of self-discharge The self-discharge is the term associated with the rapid voltage drop and energy loss of supercapacitors which is especially harmful for supercapacitors. Once the voltage of supercapacitors drops to half of the initial voltage, the supercapacitors will become almost useless immediately because the first 50% of the voltage stores up to 75% of energy in supercapacitors [32]. To greatly reduce and avoid the voltage drop derived from the side effects of the self-discharge, understanding the mechanisms of the self-discharge is of vital importance [39]. Until now, there are three kinds of widely accepted mechanisms of self-discharge: (1) leakage current, (2) Faradic reaction and (3) charge redistribution. 2.1 Leakage current Generally speaking, the causes of leakage current can be categorized into two aspects: one is parasitic redox reactions near the interface between electrode and electrolyte; the other is the probable internal short-circuit when the supercapacitors are assembled and produced [40]. The relationship between the self-discharge voltage (V) of supercapacitors and the duration of self-discharge (t) is described as follows [39]. (1) V V i = exp - t RC here, Vi represents the steady voltage value at the beginning of the self-discharge, C represents the capacitance, R represents the ohmic load resistance. The above equation indeed provides the quantitatively mathematical analysis for leakage current. Further, the qualitative factors influencing the leakage current have also been reported in literature, such as electrode materials, electrolyte, operating voltage and operation temperature. For electrode materials, Nguyen et al. systematically studied the effects of composition and surface chemical properties of the pitch-derived activated carbon on the leakage current [37]. It was found that reducing the concentration of impurities and oxygen functional groups of electrode materials was beneficial to decreasing the leakage current. In the case of electrolyte, the types of solvents in electrolyte also play a noticeable role in the degree of leakage current. To illustrate this point, Kötz et al. confirmed that among three kinds of organic electrolytes including teraethylammonium tetrafluoroborate (TEABF4)/propylene carbonate (PC), TEABF4/acetonitrile (AN) and TEABF4/γ-butyrolactone (GBL), the supercapacitor with PC as solvents exhibited the lowest leakage current (5.3 mA) while 23.3 mA for GBL [41]. Moreover, the operating voltage and temperature are responsible for leakage current as well. The fundamental rule is that the leakage current increases with the rise in operation voltage and temperature, which is also discussed in the later section. 2.2 Faradic reaction For carbon-based materials, the oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of carbon and redox mediators in redox active electrolyte are able to provide the extra redox reactions [37]. Beyond that, the oxygen dissolved in electrolytes can also bring about redox reactions in the form of reduction [42]. In the EDLC system, these redox reactions are referred as Faradic reaction [40]. It is believed that the Faradic reaction will accelerate the self-discharge rate especially for EDLC because these reactant species (oxygen functional groups, redox mediators and dissolved oxygen in electrolyte) can accept/donate the electrons to cause the self-discharge and the resultant voltage drop of supercapacitors. To further visually understand the detailed mechanism of Faradic reaction, as a demonstration of with negatively charged electrode, the charge loss derived from Faradic reaction on negative electrode and the decay of electrode potential (ψ 0) is shown in Fig. 3 . In this regard, the ferric ions would accept the negative charges via reduction reaction, leading to the self-discharge. Depending on the concentration of reactant species, the Faradic reaction for supercapacitors can be classified into two branches: activation-controlled reaction and diffusion-controlled reaction [32]. When the concentration of reactant species is high enough, the impact of concentration on Faradic reaction rate can be ignored. Therefore, the mechanism of Faradic reaction induced self-discharge can be dominated by activation-controlled reaction and the corresponding voltage after the self-discharge can be described as follows. (2) V t = - R T α F ln α Fi 0 R TC - R T α F ln t + C τ i 0 here, Vt represents the self-discharge voltage, R is the gas constant, T represents the temperature, α is the transfer coefficient, F represents the constant of Faraday, i 0 represents the exchange current–density, C represents the interfacial capacitance and τ represents the integration constant. On the contrary, if the concentration of reactant species is low enough, it will take a long time for the reactant species to pass through EDL and to be oxidized or reduced near the surface of electrode. In this case, the mechanism is diffusion-controlled and the corresponding voltage after the self-discharge can be described as follows. (3) V t = V i - 2 zFAD 1 / 2 π - 1 / 2 c 0 C t 1 / 2 here, Vi represents the initial charging voltage, z represents the charge of reactant species, D represents the diffusion coefficient, c0 represents the starting concentration of reactant species, and A represents the area of electrode. Also, the diffusion-controlled mechanism could also be simplified as: V t = V i - mt 1 / 2 here, m is the diffusion coefficient. By fitting the experimental data with mathematical equations discussed above, the inherent self-discharge mechanism can be identified. To illustrate this point, Wang et al. studied the self-discharge mechanism of supercapacitors with carbon cloth as electrode and CuCl2/H2SO4 as electrolyte, respectively [43]. It was found that the self-discharge curves fitted well with diffusion-controlled mechanism. The calculated correlation coefficient reached 0.99, indicative of a high degree of fitting. Finally, it was demonstrated that the mechanism was diffusion-controlled mechanism. 2.3 Charge redistribution When the supercapacitor is fully charged and the external power supply is removed subsequently, there is no sufficient time for charges to distribute homogeneously in pores of electrode materials such as activated carbon [44]. Most of the charges simply gather in the tip of pores and move towards the deep of pores driven by the concentration difference of charges while they are significantly hindered by the strong resistance. The resistance to ionic movement in small pores was far bigger than that in electrolyte, being 4 orders of magnitude [35]. As a result, the spontaneous voltage drop will happen and the phenomenon mentioned above is the main cause of the self-discharge which is also called as charge redistribution (Fig. 4 ). In this case, the pore size of electrode materials plays a key role in the charge redistribution. For instance, Laheäär et al. studied the impact of size matching between pore size of the activated carbon and the ionic diameter of electrolyte on charge redistribution. Interestingly, it was found that when replacing EMImTFSI with 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (BMImBF4) ionic-liquid electrolyte, more time was required for BMIm+ (0.65 × 0.99 nm) to distribute uniformly within the micropore (1.15 nm) of YP-80F compared with EMIm+ (0.62 × 0.81 nm) leading to the slow charge redistribution. As such, the relatively small pore size of electrolyte ions will greatly reduce the charge redistribution and the corresponding self-discharge behavior for the device can be alleviated [45]. The charge redistribution can not only accelerate the self-discharge rate but also reduce accuracy of measuring voltage since all of the voltage detecting equipment measures the voltage at the tip of pores. Unlike the leakage current and Faradic reaction, establishing the unified mathematic model to explain the charge redistribution is challenging. Therefore, to better fit the non-linear curves of voltage drop caused by charge redistribution and predict final discharge voltage, the equivalent circuit models (ECMs) with three branches and a leakage resistance have been presented [46]. To clarify the impact of initial voltage on ECMs and accurately predict the final self-discharge voltage derived from charge redistribution, Shen et al. constructed a polynomial equation related to initial voltage and discovered that accuracy was acceptable when the polynomial orders increased into five [46]. Also, lots of mathematical models including first-principle electrochemical model, data-driven empirical model were presented to further describe/predict the energy density and power density of the supercapacitors. For the first-principle electrochemical model, the linear dependence between the concentration and the conductivity of the electrolyte was taken into consideration using the non-linear partial differential algebraic equations [47]. For the data driven model, a four-layer neural net having two hidden layers with 6 and 15 nodes was established to simulate the capacitor performance [48]. In fact, there are some factors affecting charge redistribution such as the charge current density and the holding time after supercapacitors are fully charged. The self-discharge rate is proportional to the charge current density, where the low charge current density allows the ions near electrode surface to have much time to form more stable EDL, finally restricting the self-discharge process [36]. It was also pointed out that after the supercapacitors were fully charged, prolonging the holding time indeed slowed the self-discharge rate, because this can help to promote the homogenous distribution of charges in EDL and the formation of the stable EDL [49]. 2.4 The hybrid mechanisms Due to the complexity of each component for supercapacitors including the electrode, the electrolyte and the separator, the self-discharge mechanisms are likely to be controlled by the hybrid mechanisms that are the combination of leakage current, Faradic reaction, and charge redistribution [39]. For instance, Xia et al. combined the leakage current, activation-controlled and diffusion-controlled Faradic reaction to fit the self-discharge curves of supercapacitor with activated carbon electrodes [50]. It was found that the hybrid mechanism shown in Eq. (4) could perfectly fit the self-discharge curves: (4) U = U 0 exp - t RC - m t 1 2 - a - b ln t + C K i 0 here, a, b represent the constants of Faradic process and K represents the integration constant. As is well known to us, during the self-discharge process, the ions in the electrolyte can move only when the driving forces outstripped the drag force [40]. There are two fundamental driving forces in EDLC. One is the potential driving force derived from the potential difference (ΔU = V) and V represents the voltage of supercapacitors. The other is diffusion driving force derived from the concentration gradient. Based on the driving forces, the self-discharge mechanism can also be classified into the potential-driven model (V = V initiale− t / RC) and diffusion-controlled model (V = V initial-mt 1/2). Zhang et al. investigated the self-discharge mechanism for supercapacitors with lithium hexafluorophosphate in ethylene carbonate-diethyl carbonate (LiPF6/EC-DEC) and TEABF4/PC. For the supercapacitor with LiPF6/EC-DEC, the self-discharge voltage drop (V initial-V) was proportional to the square root of the self-discharge time (t 1/2), indicating that the self-discharge mechanism was diffusion-controlled model caused by concentration gradient (Fig. 5 a) [36]. For the supercapacitor with TEABF4/PC, which was different from that in LiPF6/EC-DEC, at the high voltage, the lnV could be fitted well with t. While at the low voltage, there was a linear relationship between the self-discharge voltage drop and t 1/2, indicating that the self-discharge mechanism was the combination of potential-driven and diffusion-controlled model. Such a self-discharge mechanism was named as the dual-mechanism (Fig. 5b). 3 Strategies for suppressing the self-discharge In conclusion, the self-discharge imposes the great adverse influences on the practical utilization of supercapacitors. As illustrated in the above section, about 5%–60% loss of voltage would happen within two weeks for the fast self-discharge process. Therefore, a series of novel and feasible strategies depending on mechanisms of the self-discharge have been reported to suppress the self-discharge. Herein, the strategies available now are considered by the three aspects: modifying the electrode materials, modulating the electrolyte and tuning the separator. 3.1 Modifying the electrode materials As discussed in the above section, the leakage current, the Faradic reaction and the charge redistribution are responsible for the self-discharge of supercapacitors and have close relation with electrode materials. Up to now, the carbon-based electrode materials have been widely applied in supercapacitors, indicative of the importance of suppressing the self-discharge for carbon-based materials [51–54]. The extensively used carbon materials are activated carbon (AC), graphene and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [55–57]. Hence, to reduce and avoid the self-discharge derived from these carbon-based materials is very necessary and the corresponding strategies are summarized and discussed as follows. 3.1.1 Activated carbon Activated carbon with sp 3-hybridized structure is the most widely used porous carbonaceous materials together with high surface area and porous channels for fast transport of the electrolyte ions [58–61]. It can be obtained by physical or chemical activation methods with biomass, petroleum, pitch, and coal as carbon source [11,62–67]. However, the naturally and widely available raw materials for activated carbon can bring about different degrees of impurities and functional groups leading to the accelerated self-discharge rate of supercapacitors assembled with the as-obtained activated carbon as electrodes. Moreover, the pore effects derived from their particularly hierarchical pore structure within the activated carbon will aggravate the charge redistribution. More precisely, once the supercapacitor was charged under a few hundred Amperes, the majority of the charges mainly gathered in the macro-pores and it will take a long time for charges to homogeneously redistribute within the pore system (macro-, meso- and micro-pores), which finally triggered the self-discharge [35]. To address the above mentioned issues, many of the different strategies have been developed and adopted. Xie et al. treated the petroleum coke-based activated carbon in a flowing hydrogen at a high temperature and investigated the effects of heat treatment with H2 on the pore properties and surface chemistry of activated carbon as well as the self-discharge [38]. It was discovered that heat treatment with H2 mainly reduced the number of oxygen functional groups on the surface of activated carbon such as carbonyl groups. As a result, the electron transfer resistance and the self-discharge rate displayed a decrease. As a contrast, the activated carbon was also treated in 60% HNO3 yielding AC-HNO3 with abundant oxygen functional groups. Correspondingly, the equivalent series resistance (ESR) for AC-HNO3 (6.8 Ohm) increased in comparison to that of AC-H2 (2.1 Ohm). It was concluded that decreasing the number of oxygen functional groups indeed led to the small ESR and the slow self-discharge rate in both acid and alkaline electrolytes. Moreover, it was pointed out that the oxygen functional groups would hinder the interaction between electrolyte ions and carbonaceous materials and bring about the undesired parasitic Faradic reaction, leading to the enhanced leakage current [68]. For example, Yuan and coworkers investigated the impact of the specific oxygen functional groups on the self-discharge [69]. It was found that for supercapacitor with Spiro-(1,1)-bipyrrolidinium tetrafluoroboratetetraethyl ammonium tetrafluoroborate/propylene carbonate organic electrolyte, only the COOH and RCOOR functional groups on carbon surface were responsible for the fast self-discharge, while other oxygen functional groups including CO and CO with thermal stability had no relation with the fast self-discharge. For the as-made starch-based porous carbon without COOH and RCOOR, the leakage current was only 0.001 mA, much lower than the raw starch-based porous carbon (0.022 mA). Sutarsis and coworkers treated commercial activated carbon with melamine, ammonia gas/argon and nitric oxide (NO) to finely tune the content of N-containing functional groups of activated carbon [70]. Subsequently, the leakage current for supercapacitor electrodes with different N-containing levels was evaluated in the propylene carbonate electrolyte. The activated carbon with more N-O possessed the lowest leakage current because the N-O with positive charges could suppress the nucleophilic attack. Also the N-5 and N-6 with negative charges could accelerate the propylene carbonate ring opening, causing the enhancement of the leakage current. In fact, the self-discharge behavior of carbon materials with abundant nitrogen species was related to the used electrolytes. The nitrogen-enriched carbon electrodes exhibited the biggest leakage current and fastest self-discharge rate in 6 M KOH, much higher and faster than that with 1 M H2SO4 [71]. In fact, when the carbon-based electrodes go through charging or discharging process, the carbon materials will undergo the chemical oxidation, which further trigger the self-discharge. Oickle et al. studied the effects of carbon oxidation on the self-discharge behaviors of activated carbon-based supercapacitor in H2SO4 electrolyte [72]. It was well known that carbon oxidation would occur on the oxidation sites of carbon surface when the applied voltage on positive electrode was higher than 0.6 V. During the period of carbon oxidation, the carbon materials would release electrons to neutralize the positive charges of EDL leading to the self-discharge and the loss of stored energy. In this case, the repeated charge/self-discharge strategy was proposed to eliminate the impacts of carbon oxidation on the self-discharge. Furthermore, the self-discharge charges (Q SD, total, as-received) of supercapacitors without being treated with charge/self-discharge strategy were divided into three parts: charge redistribution (CR); carbon oxidation (SD, C-ox); other possible driving force such as Faradic reaction (SD, other) and the corresponding equation was shown in Eq. (5): (5) Q SD, total, as-received = Q CR + Q SD, C-ox + Q SD, other For electrodes that were fully treated with repeated charge/self-discharge strategy, the charge loss derived from the carbon oxidation (SD, C-ox) was eliminated because the surface active sites were worked out and the corresponding equation was changed into Eq. (6): (6) Q SD, total, oxidized = Q CR + Q SD, other On the basis of this, it was found that, the voltage drop was reduced 115 mV and the self-discharge was reduced by 50% [72]. At the same time, the surface of electrode is the place where the Faradic reaction happens, which will cause the self-discharge. Passivating the surface of electrode with insulation film is also regarded as the efficient path to reduce the Faradic reaction and further suppress the self-discharge. Tevi et al. electrochemically deposited p-phenylene oxide (PPO) blocking layer (1.5 nm) on activated carbon to suppress the self-discharge [73]. The PPO blocking layer hindered the direct interaction between charges on the surface of electrode and electrolyte ions (Fig. 5c and d), and hence increasing the energy barrier of Faradic reaction. Eventually, with the insulating layer (PPO), the leakage current was reduced to 220 μA, compared with the one without the PPO layer (996 μA), evidently suppressing the self-discharge process. Also, it was pointed out that although electrodeposition of dielectric film was an efficient way to minimize the leakage current, the thickness of blocking layer should be thin enough (1 nm at most) to avoid the loss of capacitance [73]. 3.1.2 Graphene Two dimensional and sp 2-hybridized graphene with typical flat sheet structure, is composed of six honeycomb carbon lattices [17,74]. Usually it is as thick as a carbon atom [10]. Graphene has sparked huge interest due to the high specific surface area (2630 m2 g−1), the large in-plane conductivity and the excellently theoretical capacitance for EDLC (550 F g−1), etc. [75–78]. Once the total surface can be well utilized, the resultant performance in supercapacitors is greatly boosted. At present, the most effective method to prepare graphene is to reduce graphene oxide by chemical reduction methods [79]. However, the residual of oxygen functional groups cause the severe self-discharge. To solve this problem, various strategies have been put forward. For instance, Subramanian et al. studied the self-discharge mechanisms of graphene-based supercapacitors in TEABF4/PC electrolyte [49]. A combined self-discharge mechanism derived from leakage current and charge redistribution was proposed and confirmed, which was also different from other carbon-based supercapacitors. Subsequently, it was found that after supercapacitors were fully charged, increasing the holding time and decreasing the initial voltage of self-discharge were both beneficial for suppressing the self-discharge. Wang et al. reported a molten-salt (including LiCl; KCl; KNO3) strategy to produce graphene with less amount of oxygen functional groups [80]. Typically, the graphene oxide was homogeneously mixed with the molten salts. Subsequently the mixture was heated under 600 °C to produce graphene. The extra addition of salts could reduce the melting point of the mixture. During the heating process, the dehydration reaction between hydroxyl and oxygen groups would reduce the amount of oxygen functional groups, leading to the low self-discharge rate. For comparison, the conventional thermal reduced graphene without salts was also prepared. Finally, when the self-discharge voltage reduced from 3 V to 2 V, the required time for graphene with molten salts (0.9 h) was prolonged in comparison to that of conventional thermal reduced graphene (0.36 h). The prolonged time further confirmed the significant effects of molten-salts in suppressing the self-discharge [80]. Li et al. synthesized the three dimensional electrode made of graphene and polyaniline (3D-G/PANI) (Fig. 6 a) [81]. The corresponding all solid-state supercapacitors (ASSs) with 3D-G/PANI electrode and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)-H2SO4 gel electrolytes showed an ultra-low leakage current. It was believed that the 3D-G/PANI electrode exhibited excellent mechanical flexibility and the ASSs assembled by it were operated without current collectors. The absence of current collectors in ASSs prevented the possible leakage current and parasitic Faradic reaction. Also, the ultrahigh conductivity (1957 S m−1) and hierarchical porous structure for 3D-G/PANI electrode accelerated the charge transfer. On the basis of these integrated superiorities, the leakage current could be reduced from 28 µA to 11.7 µA. 3.1.3 Carbon nanotubes One dimensional carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with cylindrical structure that are built by rolling graphene sheet unit, have also been used in supercapacitors due to high surface area and fast charge mobility [82–86]. To boost the functionalities of original CNTs, it is essential to modify the CNTs from hydrophobic to hydrophilic surface [87]. Such treatment will increase the number of oxygen functional groups and lead to self-discharge. To deal with the trade-off effects, it is important to understand the self-discharge mechanisms of CNTs-based supercapacitors and propose the relevant strategies to suppress the self-discharge. Zhang et al. prepared the single wall nanotube (SWNT) microfilm electrode with very fewer oxygen functional groups to suppress the self-discharge [88]. The SWNT derived from chemical vapor deposition strategy was then heated at 400 °C to remove the oxygen groups on its surface. The corresponding product was named as r-SWNT. As a contrast, the SWNT samples were also soaked in KMnO4 to introduce the more oxygen functional groups and the corresponding product was o-SWNT. Ultimately, in the same voltage drop 1.5 V from 2 V to 0.5 V, it spent 12.27 h for r-SWNT with oxygen functional groups of 8.9% while only 4.15 h for o-SWNT with oxygen functional groups of 22.1%. The reduced self-discharge rate implied that the less the concentration of oxygen functional groups was, the lower the self-discharge rate would be. To meet the commercial requirements of portable electronic equipment including laptops, sensors and smart phones, a series of ultra-thin and flexible solid-state supercapacitors have been developed [89–92]. Flexible solid-state supercapacitors are also very sensitive to the self-discharge. Usually, the CNTs with high conductivity and mechanical properties are selected as the electrode materials for the solid-state supercapacitors. Meng et al. used polyaniline to modify the surface of CNTs and a thin aniline layer (50–90 nm) was covered on the surface of CNTs (Fig. 6b) [93]. The formed polyaniline layer played an important role in restricting the self-discharge because the PANI-derived interface between electrode and solid electrolyte can increase the resistance of the other species in carbon electrode accessible to the electrolyte ions. With the coating of PANI, the leakage current was only 17.2 µA and 57.6% of the voltage was still maintained even if the supercapacitors were placed in the open circuit state for 24 h [93]. 3.2 Modulating the electrolyte At present, the widely used electrolytes in supercapacitors are aqueous and organic electrolytes [94–96]. Meanwhile, the redox electrolytes have also become the promising generation of electrolytes because the redox couples will contribute to the extra pseudocapacitance [97–99]. The self-discharge behaviors are also affected by electrolytes. For instance, the diameter of electrolyte ions and the viscosity of electrolytes have the significant effects on the charge redistribution and the Faradic reaction. Hence, modulating these electrolytes to suppress the self-discharge is essential and the related strategies are summed up as follows. 3.2.1 Aqueous electrolytes Although the aqueous electrolytes are widely used in supercapacitors, the narrow potential windows and resultant inferior energy density still inhibit their practical applications [100–102]. However, the extensive efforts are to broaden the work voltage window of aqueous electrolytes in the laboratory [103,104]. Basically, the aqueous electrolytes can be simply categorized into acid, alkaline and natural electrolytes [95,105]. At the same time, the aqueous supercapacitors are accompanied by self-discharge [106]. Interestingly, the positive and negative electrodes follow the different self-discharge mechanisms: the former is activation-controlled mechanism while the latter is diffusion-controlled mechanism [107]. More specifically, the reduction of dissolved oxygen in electrolyte and impurity contamination can severely induce and accelerate the self-discharge [42]. For the reduction of dissolved oxygen in electrolyte, usually, the dissolved oxygen in electrolyte could be reduced into H2O or H2O2. And the reduction of dissolved oxygen would consume the charges on surface of electrodes. Subsequently, the charges inside the pores would make up for the loss of charge in the form of charge redistribution, finally leading to the self-discharge. Oickle and Andreas bubbled 1.0 M H2SO4 with oxygen and nitrogen to change the concentration of O2 in aqueous electrolyte, respectively [42]. The concentration of dissolved O2 in H2SO4 electrolyte increased when bubbled with oxygen and decreased when bubbled with N2. The results proved that increasing the concentration of oxygen will consume the charges and oxygen indeed accelerated the self-discharge rate. For impurity contamination, the impact of Fe ions in aqueous electrolyte on the self-discharge was presented as an example. Once the aqueous electrolytes contained the ferric and ferrous ions, the oxidation reaction on anode (Fe2+ – e− = Fe3+) and the reduction reaction (Fe3+ + e− = Fe2+) on cathode would occur. The resultant Fe ions-induced Faradic reaction will consume the charges stored in EDL, leading to the self-discharge [107]. Moreover, replacing the aqueous electrolytes with other electrolytes or combining aqueous solvent with the specific salt is also concerned. Wang et al. substituted the aqueous electrolyte with the bentonite clay@ionic liquid electrolyte (BIES) (Fig. 7 a) [34]. The extra addition of bentonite clay was the key point for reducing the self-discharge rate. Specifically, the bentonite clay was rich in silicon and oxygen elements (Si-O bonds) providing the confinement effect for restricting the diffusion of cations. Moreover, the bentonite clay was able to adsorb contamination such as Fe3+ and O2 and hence further reduce the Faradic reaction (Fig. 7b). After 60 h self-discharge, the final voltage for supercapacitors with BIES could still maintain 28.9% (0.87 V). Even when the temperature was higher than 75 °C, the output voltage was still higher than 1.5 V after 12 h of self-discharge, showing the remarkably suppressed self-discharge. Avirddy et al. reported supercapacitors on the basis of WIS electrolyte made of water and potassium acetate rather than conventional aqueous electrolyte, displaying the significant effects to suppress the self-discharge [108]. It was found that the ionic movement was greatly impeded owing to the high viscosity of WIS electrolyte (>10 mPa s−1), with the near solid–liquid interface, and hence the loss of charges was restrained. In the end, such a WIS electrolyte into asymmetric supercapacitors with Ti3C2 and MnO2 as negative and positive electrodes, respectively, after 30,000 s of self-discharge, the final self-discharge voltage was 1.5 V, with a retention of 68% compared with the 2.2 V of initial voltage. 3.2.2 Organic electrolytes In general, the organic electrolytes are made up of organic solvents and conducting salts [94]. The resultant supercapacitors are now dominating a huge portion of commercial market because of its high and stable operating voltage window (2.6 V–2.9 V) [109–111]. The mechanisms of the self-discharge in organic electrolyte system are different from others. On the one hand, the average size of the organic molecules is relatively big, making it hard to access the electrode surface. On the other hand, the organic electrolytes are more viscous than aqueous electrolytes and more susceptible to the temperature. As such, for the self-discharge of organic electrolytes, the new electrorheological (ER) effects have been reported and detailed discussions are as follows [50]. Xia et al. added nematic liquid crystal 4-n-pentyl-4′-cyanobiphenyl (5CB) (2 vol%) into triethylmethylammonium tetrafluoroborate (TEMABF4)/acetonitrile to suppress the self-discharge [50]. When being charged, the 5CB molecules would be in ordered alignment. Meanwhile, the orientation of 5CB molecules would be perpendicular to the electrode derived from electrorheological (ER) effect, leading to the increased viscosity of the electrolyte near the surface of electrode (Fig. 7c and d). Combined with the calculation results, it was revealed that when the 5CB molecules were added, the diffusion parameter greatly reduced compared to the one without 5CB. Therefore, thanks to the well-tuned fluid rheological properties of the electrolyte during the charging process, the diffusion the electrolyte ions and parasitic impure species diffuse out of EDL would be hindered to a great extent. Accordingly, the charge redistribution was alleviated and the suppressed self-discharge was achieved. More importantly, during the discharging process, the 5CB molecules would be in a huge disorder, where the ER effect disappeared, finally, the capacitive behavior of the supercapacitor was not affected. With the ER effect, the open-circuit voltage could still maintain higher than 1.42 V even after 24 h of self-discharge. 3.2.3 Redox active electrolytes Redox active electrolytes gain much attention because the redox mediators can also provide the extra pseudocapacitance [97,99,112–114]. For example, when the redox mediator was K3[Fe(CN6)], during the charging and discharging process, the reverse Faradic reaction will happen to enhance capacitive performance. As a result, the functionalized porous carbon-based supercapacitor electrolyte made of 1 M Na2SO4/0.03 M K3Fe(CN6) exhibited a capacitance of 454F g−1@1 A g−1 [115]. For redox active electrolytes, choosing the suitable redox mediators is very important. Until now, various kinds of redox mediators have been extensively reported including KI, Cu2SO4, hydroquinone (HQ), methylene blue and so on [116–118]. However, the related work has indicated that the redox active electrolyte will cause the severe self-discharge issue [119]. Therefore, the strategies for suppressing the self-discharge of redox active electrolytes must be taken into consideration. Chen et al. studied the self-discharge mechanism of supercapacitors in hydroquinone (HQ)/H2SO4 electrolyte [120]. The different self-discharge models were chosen to fit the experimental curves of self-discharge. It was confirmed that the diffusion-controlled mechanism was responsible for the rapid self-discharge process. As shown in Fig. 8 (a), the HQ was oxidized into p-benzoquinone (BQ) on the positive electrode during charging period. After removing the external voltage, the BQ molecules will migrate to negative electrode due to the concentration difference between two electrodes, i.e. the shuttle effects (Fig. 8b). Subsequently the BQ molecules were reduced into HQ molecules leading to the fast self-discharge. Therefore, inhibiting the shuttle effects of BQ from the positive electrode to the negative electrode was essential. To address this issue, the selective Nafion membrane as separator that only the hydrogen ions was allowed to pass, was adopted to prevent the BQ molecules from migrating (Fig. 8c). Moreover, to completely avoid the shuttle effects of BQ molecules, another specific redox electrolyte (CuSO4/H2SO4) was chosen, because Cu2+ could be reduced into undissolved product (Cu) during charging on the negative electrode. In this case, the undissolved Cu was not able to migrate to the positive electrode after the supercapacitor was fully charged (Fig. 8d). In the end, when the self-discharge voltage varied from 0.8 V to 0.3 V, the self-discharge time for supercapacitor with HQ/H2SO4 electrolyte and Nafion membrane, and supercapacitor with CuSO4/H2SO4 and cellulose acetate membrane was 4686 s and 7727 s, respectively, in comparison to that with HQ/H2SO4 electrolyte and cellulose acetate membrane (1462 s). The gradually and dramatically increased decay time indicated the effectively suppressed self-discharge, indicative of the effectiveness of the presented method. Although the deposition of Cu at the negative electrode indeed suppressed the self-discharge, the insoluble Cu also inevitably caused the undesired pore blockage effects and the resultant deterioration of cycle stability. It was confirmed that, owning to the deposition of Cu, the capacitance retention for supercapacitor with PVA/CuCl2/H2SO4 solid electrolyte was merely 35% after 3000 cycles [43]. To deal with this issue, Wang et al. constructed the dual-solid state supercapacitor with PVA/H2SO4 negative electrolyte and PVA/CuCl2/H2SO4 positive electrolyte, which finally suppressed the self-discharge. In the meanwhile, the PVA played the important role in lowering the kinetics of the self-discharge. In the end, the capacitance retention was improved to 92% [43]. Chun et al. compared the self-discharge behaviors of supercapacitors in the presence of different redox couples including 1,1′-dimethyl-4,4′-bipyridinium dichloride (MVCl2)/KBr and 1,1′-Diheptyl-4,4′-bipyridinium dibromide (HVBr2) [121]. During the charging period, the MV2+ and HV2+ ions in electrolyte were reduced to MV+ and HV+, while the Br− ion was oxidized to Br3 − (Fig. 9 a and b). After fully charged, due to the activated carbon featuring more strongly physical adsorption capability for HV+ than MV+, the shuttle effects of redox HV+ between electrodes were greatly suppressed and the self-discharge behavior was relatively slow. For the supercapacitor with MVCl2/KBr, the self-discharge rate was as slow as the commercial Cellergy capacitor. Also, for one with HVBr2, the self-discharge rate was more comparable to the commercial Maxwell capacitor. With the same principle, Fan et al. creatively added CNTs into the electrolyte of quasi-solid-state (PVA-Li2SO4-BMIMBr) supercapacitors to suppress the self-discharge. Originally, the BMIMBr could cause the self-discharge because of the reduction reaction of Br3 − on the negative electrode. After adding the CNTs, the Br3 − could be adsorbed on its surface. Furthermore, the 3-dimentional CNTs could inhibit the spontaneous diffusion of Br3 −. Eventually, after 5 h of self-discharge, the final open-circuit voltage for the supercapacitor with CNTs was evidently improved (1.18 V) in comparison with the one without CNTs (0.62 V) when the supercapacitors were charged to 1.8 V [122]. 3.3 Tuning the separator The separator in supercapacitors insulates the negative and the positive electrodes and exerts the enormous influences on the movement of electrolyte ions [123,124]. At present, the commonly used separator is Nafion separator with traits of highly electrochemical stability and long lifetime [125]. Although the Nafion separator can selectively allow the migration of hydrogen ions and inhibit the shuttle effects of other ions to some degree, the effects for suppressing the self-discharge are still unsatisfying. It was found that the separator with the negative or positive charges can control the ionic movement, thus the corresponding shuttle effects were inhibited. As a result, tuning the separator was a useful strategy to suppress the self-discharge. For example, Peng et al. prepared the sodium dodecyl benzene sulfonate (SDBS)-modified polyacrylonitrile (PAN) membrane (PAN@SDBS) through the coaxial electrospinning [126]. Specifically, the PAN was dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) as the core solution and the SDBS was dissolved in DMF as the sheath solution. Subsequently, through the coaxial electrospinning, the PAN@SDBS nanofiber membrane made of the PAN core and SDBS shell was prepared. Due to existence of SDBS, in 2 M of KOH solution, the contact angle was 0° for PAN@SDBS membrane while 115° for the PAN nanofiber membrane, showing that the PAN@SDBS had the unique wettability. Moreover, the SDBS-modified nanofiber membrane with homogeneous elements (Na, S, O, N) could release Na+ into electrolyte, leaving the nanofiber membrane with negative charges. Once the supercapacitor was fully charged, the ions in the EDL would spontaneously move because of the high and negative Gibbs free energy and concentration variation. However, the migration of negative ions towards the negative electrode was hindered by the negatively charged PAN@SDBS separator. Accordingly, with PAN@SDBS membrane, the stable voltage for the supercapacitor was 0.58 V after the self-discharge, much higher than the one with traditional commercial membrane (MPF30AC) (0.38 V), showing the efficiency of the PAN@SDBS separator for slowing the self-discharge rate [126]. Wang et al prepared the polyethyleneimine (PEI)-modified cellulose separator (CS) by immersing the CS in PEI aqueous solution [127]. In the aqueous electrolyte, for the modified PEI-CS separator, the measured zeta potential (+40.42 mV) increased compared with that of cellulose (0 mV), indicating that the PEI-CS separator had the positive charges. Hence, when the supercapacitor was fully charged, the PEI-CS separator can suppress the movement of cation. To quantitatively explore the impact of PEI-CS separator on the ionic movement, the open-circuit voltage for the single negative electrode with CS (V NCS) (Eq. (7)) and PEI-CS (V NPEI-CS-2) (Eq. (8)) was recorded, respectively. It was found that both of the curves of the open-circuit voltage fitted well with the diffusion-controlled model. Meanwhile, the diffusion coefficient was reduced from 0.118 for CS to 0.075 for PEI-CS. The diffusion coefficient was determined by the ionic movement of electrolyte. In this case, the decreased diffusion coefficient indicated the restrained diffusion of electrolyte ions. Eventually, for the supercapacitor with the PEI-CS separator, after the self-discharge for 10 h with the initial voltage of 0.8 V, the final open-circuit voltage was 0.22 V, being significantly higher than the one with only CS separator (0.13 V) [127]. (7) V NCS = 0.026 + 0.018 t 1 / 2 (8) V NPEI - CS = 0 . 039 + 0.075 t 1/2 4 Conclusions and outlook The fully charged supercapacitors with high and negative Gibbs free energy spontaneously occur the charge loss and voltage drop, leading to the self-discharge that is generally existed in it. The self-discharge process is indeed unbeneficial for the practical application of supercapacitors and impossible to be eliminated absolutely so far. What can be done is to effectively suppress the self-discharge rate to the lowest point and the corresponding strategies have also been built and reviewed. In brief, the strategies to suppress the self-discharge mainly focus on modifying the electrode materials, modulating the electrolytes and tuning the separator. Also, the unresolved issues and the development prospects for suppressing the self-discharge are as follows. (I) For carbon-based electrodes, the abundant resource of raw materials will bring about the tough issues such as ash content and oxygen-containing functional groups in the as-made carbon materials, which will cause the self-discharge. Up to now, reducing the oxygen functional groups of carbonaceous electrodes with hydrogen treatment before the electrodes are used, has been proved to be valid in lowering the self-discharge rate. Besides, the porous structure also leads to severe charge redistribution within the carbonaceous materials and now the confirmed effective strategy is to prolong the holding time after supercapacitors are fully charged, thus finally providing more time for charges to uniformly distribute within pores. Although the tremendous advances in suppressing self-discharge have been achieved, the mechanisms of the self-discharge for supercapacitors need to be further decoupled by in-situ and/or ex-situ techniques and the behaviors for the self-discharge of supercapacitors are often ignored in the present and absent for a long time. Hence, more efforts are urgently required to be devoted to these aspects above mentioned. What is more, establishing the overall evaluation criteria to evaluate the self-discharge process of different carbon-based materials systemically is also essential. (II) For electrolyte, the operation voltage window should be strictly controlled within the stable voltage window of electrolytes. Especially, for aqueous electrolyte, the stable voltage window is only 1.23 V. Once the operation voltage is too high, the decomposition of electrolyte will happen to consume the charges leading to the self-discharge. Also, the electrolyte should keep the high purity to avoid the contamination of oxygen in aqueous electrolyte and water in organic electrolyte. Up to now, the reported feasible strategy for aqueous electrolyte to suppress the self-discharge is to replace the aqueous electrolyte with other electrolytes such as ionic liquid electrolyte. As for organic electrolyte, the unique ER effect of the used 5CB molecules in it is useful, suggesting that the novel and effective materials with ER effect were highly desired. In the case of redox active electrolyte, choosing the specific redox couple such as CuSO4, together with utilizing the materials with the well adsorption capability towards the redox couples in electrode or electrolyte to inhibit the shuttle effects, are verified to be effective in lowering the self-discharge rate. But the remained challenge for modulating electrolyte to suppress the self-discharge requires the deep understanding and the building of morphology for the self-discharge mechanism, such as the purity and the shuttle effects of species, the stability of electrolytes at a high voltage. In a nutshell, to suppress the self-discharge, sacrificing the charge transfer rate is unavoidable, which will cause the deterioration of rate ability and cycle stability of the supercapacitors. Therefore, how to balance the relationship between the suppressed self-discharge and advanced electrochemical performance of supercapacitors are indeed tough issues. (III) For separator, it is pointed out that the effective and promising direction to suppress the self-discharge is to make use of the membrane with negative or positive charges to inhibit the shuttle effects of electrolytes ions. Once the migration of charges in EDL between two electrodes is hindered, the suppressed self-discharge is achieved. Also, developing the separator with ionic selectivity is interesting and meaningful. In other words, the reported approach to tuning the separator is still not enough, which suggests that the novel methods are currently needed to modify separator to well suppress the self-discharge. As outlined above, the involved mechanisms and the suppressing strategies for the self-discharge are mainly related to the EDLC. In the view of the fact that the pseudocapacitor is another important emerging branch of supercapacitors and even possesses the more complicated energy storage mechanism and the complex self-discharge process, decoupling the self-discharge of these pseudocapacitors still remain the major challenge although the related work is also present. Paleo et al found that for supercapacitors with MnO2 electrode, the mechanisms of self-discharge were charge redistribution and parasitic Faradic reaction [128]. Wang et al. annealed Ti3C2T x MXene films at 400 °C to finely reduce the content of F element. It was discovered that the decline of F content would lower the leakage current [30]. Huang et al. reported the phosphorene-based zinc hybrid supercapacitor with suppressed self-discharge [129]. In the future, the strategies to suppress the self-discharge of supercapacitors, particularly oriented towards the pseudocapacitor, are still the necessary to which great endeavors are directed. Li, Q. Yang, Y. Guo, Z. Chen, Q. Li, B. Dong and C. Zhi, Adv. Energy Mater. 10 (2020) 2001024. Kunlun Liu received his B.S. degree from China University of Mining and Technology in 2019. He is currently a M.S. candidate at Dalian University of Technology under the supervision of Prof. Chang Yu from Dalian University of Technology. His research mainly focuses on the carbon-based electric double layer supercapacitors and the relevant self-discharge of supercapacitors. Chang Yu received her Ph.D. degree from the School of Chemical Engineering at Dalian University of Technology in 2008. She is currently a full professor at School of Chemical Engineering at Dalian University of Technology, and the winner of the Outstanding Youth Fellowship supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China. Her research interests mainly focus on the preparation of value-added/functional carbon and their coupled two-dimensional inorganic layered materials, and their application in supercapacitors, thermal/electrocatalytic conversion of small molecules and fine chemicals. Wei Guo received his B.S. degree from the School of Chemical Engineering at China University of Mining and Technology in 2015. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate at Dalian University of Technology under the supervision of Prof. Chang Yu and Prof. Jieshan Qiu. His research interests focus on design and synthesis of carbon-based advanced nanomaterials for high-performance energy storage and conversion device. Lin Ni received his B.S. degree from School of Chemical Engineering at the Dalian University of Technology in 2017. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate in Prof. Jieshan Qiu’s group at Dalian University of Technology. His research interests mainly focus on rational design and optimization of carbon-based nanohybrids for heterogeneous catalysis. Jinhe Yu received his B.S. degree from the Anhui University of Technology in 2017. And now, he is a Ph.D. candidate at Dalian University of Technology under the supervision of Prof. Chang Yu. His current research focuses on porous carbon-based nanomaterials for energy storage and conversion application, specifically supercapacitors. Yuanyang Xie obtained his B.S. degree from Anhui University of Technology in 2018. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate under the supervision of Prof. Chang Yu from Dalian University of Technology. His research focuses on carbon-based nanomaterials and their applications in energy storage and conversion device. Zhao Wang received his M.S. degree from the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at Shandong University of Technology in 2017. He is a Ph.D. candidate at Dalian University of Technology under the supervision of Prof. Chang Yu. His research interests mainly focus on the design of carbon-based functional materials and their applications in supercapacitors, batteries and hybrid devices. Yongwen Ren received his M.S. degree from the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at Qingdao University in 2018. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate at Dalian University of Technology under the supervision of Prof. Chang Yu. His research interests mainly focus on the design of carbon-based functional materials and their applications in electrochemical reduction of nitrogen. Jieshan Qiu received his Ph.D. degree in organic chemical engineering in 1990 from Dalian University of Technology, China. Currently, he is Cheung-Kong Distinguished Professor of Carbon Science and Chemical Engineering, and the Dean of College of Chemical Engineering at Beijing University of Chemical Technology, China. Prof. Qiu is an internationally-recognized research and thought leader in carbon science and chemical engineering. His research encompasses both fundamental and applied aspects of carbon materials and science, with a focus on the methodologies for producing carbon materials and their applications in catalysis, energy storage and conversion.

coredata.dc:description: Supercapacitors are one of the most promising energy storage devices in the fields of vehicle transportation, flexible electronic devices, aerospace, etc. However, the existed self-discharge that is the spontaneous voltage decay after supercapacitors are fully charged, brings about the wide gap between experimental studies and practical utilization of supercapacitors. Although eliminating the self-discharge completely is not reachable, suppressing the self-discharge rate to the lowest point is possible and feasible. So far, the significant endeavors have been devoted to achieve this goal. Herein, we summary and discuss the possible mechanisms for the self-discharge and the underlying influence factors. Moreover, the strategies to suppress the self-discharge are systemically summed up by three independent but unified aspects: modifying the electrode, modulating the electrolyte and tuning the separator. Finally, the major challenges to suppress the self-discharge of supercapacitors are concluded and the promising strategies are also pointed out and discussed. This review is presented with the view of serving as a guideline to suppress the self-discharge of supercapacitors and to across-the-board facilitate their widespread application.
